math.title: Math.ceil()
math.subtitle: Math.ceil(x) returns the value of x rounded up to its nearest integer

math.title: Math.floor()
math.subtitle: Math.floor(x) returns the value of x rounded down to its nearest integer.

math.title: Math.trunc()
math.subtitle: Math.trunc(x) returns the integer part of x:

math.title: math.sign()
math.subtitle: Math.sign(x) returns if x is negative, null or positive:
math.paragraph: Type a postive number , a negative number or null, example: 44, -44, null

math.title: math.pow()
math.subtitle: Math.pow(x, y) returns the value of x to the power of y:

math.title: math.sqrt()
math.subtitle: Math.sqrt(x) returns the square root of x:

math.title: math.abs()
math.subtitle: Math.abs(x) returns the absolute (positive) value of x:

math.title: math.sin()
math.subtitle: Math.sin(x) returns the sine (a value between -1 and 1) of the angle x (given in radians).
math.paragraph: If you want to use degrees instead of radians, you have to convert degrees to radians: Angle in radians = Angle in degrees x PI / 180. </br> Type your angle degree:

math.title: math.cos()
math.subtitle: Math.cos(x) returns the cosine (a value between -1 and 1) of the angle x (given in radians).
math.paragraph: If you want to use degrees instead of radians, you have to convert degrees to radians: Angle in radians = Angle in degrees x PI / 180. </br> Type your angle:

math.title: math.MinMax()
math.subtitle: Math.min() and Math.max() can be used to find the lowest or highest value in a list of arguments:
math.paragraph: In this example we will use it on this list of number to display the min and max, : [4,44,1, 300, 444, 6]
